Author: RAFAEL A GONZALEZ L
Title: The Best Scissors for Light to Medium Use Available Anywhere
Body: These Westcott scissors are perhaps far better than any other brands I have tested, and I have been through practically every one over the years (e.g. Fiskars, Scotch, TRU RED, Office Depot, and many generic brands). They cut through materials such as thin cardboard, plastic cards, and paper easily. However, from time to time, I get bad pairs right out of the box with bumps across the blades which makes for a rather poor cutting experience (i.e. the scissors don't feel smooth when opening and closing them). I recommend using a small amount light machine oil in the fulcrum area to keep them working like new. Also, wiping the blades down with a dry or mildly wet microfiber cloth helps remove any debris that can gum up the blades. I am surprised that the company does not recommend taking these measures as they can extend the life of the scissors.Rubbing alcohol will cause permanent stains on the metal, so I would recommend not using it on the blades. Contrary to the company's advertising, these scissors wear out rather quickly if frequently used for cutting tougher materials such as thick cardboard like the one found in shipping boxes. These are not quite industrial-strength scissors but should cut through most light and medium materials without any trouble. I would not recommend using these particular scissors to cut tape and other adhesive. The chemicals found in adhesive remover substances can stain the blades and ruin their precision but if it’s at all necessary to use adhesive remover, use it sparingly; Goo Gone is ideal for these situations being a light enough formula that removes adhesive without damaging metal and plastic surfaces like those found in these scissors. The lighter, drier, and less sticky the materials that are cut with these scissors are, the better for extending these scissors’ useful life.

Author: Robert James
Title: Inferior to the same exact scissors made several years ago
Body: I just returned some Amazon Basics scissors because the grind on the blades was so course you couldn't slide the blade across any material (see below). I have an old pair of Westcott Titanium scissors, the exact same as these here bought several years ago, and the grind is finer on the blades of the old pair and therefore the blades glide across materials very smoothly. These older scissors still cut well.The new ones do not slide as you cut very well at all. Because of the course grind, they hang up. Try cutting a paper towel in half by first folding the paper towel in half and creasing them and then sliding the scissors up into the fold and cut that way. You will see how the new scissors catch onto the paper and don't slide as you cut thru that fold. The old scissors glide by with no friction at all. That is because they used a fine grind on the blade. You can see the grind marks. I compared the new with the old. The new has courser grind marks. I'm sure it's cheaper to do it that way.I'm normally generous with my reviews and give 5 stars as much as I can. But when a company degrades the quality of their product like this, it is extremely disappointing. I thought I could rely on this brand.

Title: Better after breaking in
Body: Update: After using these for a week, they loosened up considerably and are now working well. The micro tips really are sharp. I’m adding stars.After using old, dull child-style scissors for my craft work, I splurged and expected these to be superior. You know how with expensive scissors, you can just feel as the blades slice past each other that they're honed fine and the slice will be smooth. These are just kind of clunky. Maybe they're not broken in yet or need oil or something, but the slice is not smooth and swift. Also, what does "micro tip" mean?
